Put-call-forward parity is derived with a forward contract rather than the underlying
asset itself. Consider a forward contract on an asset at time T with a contract price of
F(T). At contract initiation the forward contract has zero value. At time T, when the
forward contract settles, the long must purchase the asset for F,(T). The purchase (at
time=0) of a pure discount bond that will pay F,(T) at maturity (time = T) will cost
F(T) / (1 + Rf)T
